titlestmt.titleproper: Wagner Free Institute of Science electroplates 1890-1967
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

did.unittitle: Wagner Free Institute of Science electroplates

bioghist.p: Incorporated by William Wagner in 1855, the Wagner Free Institute is a natural history museum and educational institution in Philadelphia that is dedicated to providing free public education in the sciences. William Wagner originally offered free lectures and classes in his home and at Spring Garden Hall. He later constructed an Institute building, which opened to the public in 1865. The Institute's current programs and services include adult and children's programming offered onsite and at locations around Philadelphia, the Institute's library and archival collections, and a permanent display of the museum's specimen collections. Since 1891, the specimen collections have been displayed according to Darwinian principles of evolution, the organizational scheme selected by renowned biologist Joseph Leidy during his tenure as head of the Institute's scientific and educational programs in the late 19th century.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of printing plates in copper, wood, and silver-platinum. These plates were used to illustrate several of the Institute's publications, including announcements, the Bulletin, and the Transactions. Subjects include engineering drawings, shells, various views of the exterior and interior of the Institute building, field trips, rock formations, charts, and the Columbia Bridge over the Schuylkill River.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

otherfindaid.p: An inventory is available in the repository.
